<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 326, 294]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 299, 153, 314]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 278, 905, 333]]<|/det|>
0606/12 May/June 2018 2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 425, 355]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 435, 375]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Electronic calculator  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 719, 432]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 432, 320, 446]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 446, 504, 461]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 460, 504, 475]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 475, 380, 490]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 501, 282, 516]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 515, 828, 545]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 544, 593, 559]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 559, 603, 574]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 584, 606, 599]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 599, 759, 614]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 614, 437, 629]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 80.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 73, 599, 91]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 165, 561, 183]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 196, 240, 214]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 226, 383, 245]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(a x^{2} + b x + c = 0\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 243, 572, 285]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 313, 228, 330]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[242, 335, 754, 375]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n},\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 381, 494, 418]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 481, 594, 500]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 514, 156, 531]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 542, 580, 610]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 641, 242, 659]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 664, 590, 698]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 717, 593, 771]]<|/det|>
\[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\] \[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 364, 91]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(y = 1 + \tan 3x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 143, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 321, 121]]<|/det|>
State the period of \(y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 918, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 243, 141, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 243, 759, 262]]<|/det|>
On the axes below, sketch the graph of \(y = 1 + \tan 3x\) for \(0^{\circ} \leqslant x^{\circ} \leqslant 180^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 243, 918, 262]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[176, 313, 823, 693]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 97, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 96]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(k\) for which the line \(y = 1 - 2kx\) does not meet the curve \(y = 9x^{2} - (3k + 1)x + 5.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 92, 920, 111]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 70, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The variables \(x\) and \(y\) are such that when \(\mathbf{e}^{y}\) is plotted against \(x^{2}\), a straight line graph passing through the points (5, 3) and (3, 1) is obtained. Find \(y\) in terms of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 84, 920, 103]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 70, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) moves so that its displacement, \(x\) metres from a fixed point \(O\), at time \(t\) seconds, is given by \(x = \ln (5t + 3)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 116, 143, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 116, 574, 136]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(t\) when the displacement of \(P\) is \(3\mathrm{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 116, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 272, 143, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 423, 291]]<|/det|>
Find the velocity of \(P\) when \(t = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 272, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[104, 443, 141, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 441, 727, 462]]<|/det|>
Explain why, after passing through \(O\), the velocity of \(P\) is never negative.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 443, 920, 462]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[106, 628, 141, 647]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 628, 455, 647]]<|/det|>
Find the acceleration of \(P\) when \(t = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 628, 920, 647]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 87, 96, 106]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 85, 141, 104]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 78, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
The first three terms in the expansion of \(\left(3 - \frac{1}{9x}\right)^5\) can be written as \(a + \frac{b}{x} + \frac{c}{x^2}\). Find the value of each of the constants \(a, b\) and \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 100, 920, 119]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 472, 141, 491]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 470, 801, 492]]<|/det|>
Use your values of \(a, b\) and \(c\) to find the term independent of \(x\) in the expansion of

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 491, 599, 529]]<|/det|>
\[\left(3 - \frac{1}{9x}\right)^5 (2 + 9x)^2.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 502, 920, 521]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 94, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 675, 101]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of the stationary point of the curve \(y = \frac{x + 2}{\sqrt{2x - 1}}.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 78, 920, 98]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 96, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 78, 915, 102]]<|/det|>
A population, \(B\), of a particular bacterium, \(t\) hours after measurements began, is given by \(B = 1000 \mathrm{e}^{\frac{t}{4}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 114, 143, 133]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 114, 403, 133]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(B\) when \(t = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 114, 920, 133]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 238, 143, 256]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 237, 492, 256]]<|/det|>
Find the time taken for \(B\) to double in size.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 238, 920, 256]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[104, 501, 141, 520]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 501, 403, 520]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(B\) when \(t = 8\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 501, 920, 520]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 107, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 447, 89]]<|/det|>
Do not use a calculator in this question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 479, 120]]<|/det|>
All lengths in this question are in centimetres.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 134, 761, 243]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 265, 893, 284]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the triangle \(ABC\), where \(AB = 4\sqrt{3} - 5\), \(BC = 4\sqrt{3} + 5\) and angle \(ABC = 60^\circ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 289, 576, 319]]<|/det|>
It is known that \(\sin 60^\circ = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\), \(\cos 60^\circ = \frac{1}{2}\), \(\tan 60^\circ = \sqrt{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 327, 141, 345]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 327, 371, 345]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of \(AC\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 327, 920, 345]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 82, 141, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 761, 107]]<|/det|>
Hence show that \(\csc \angle ACB = \frac{2\sqrt{p}}{q} (4\sqrt{3} + 5)\), where \(p\) and \(q\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 82, 920, 101]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 102, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 92, 715, 345]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 368, 895, 400]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the graph of the curve \(y = \frac{\mathrm{e}^{4x} + 3}{8}\). The curve meets the \(y\)-axis at the point \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 400, 856, 456]]<|/det|>
The normal to the curve at \(A\) meets the \(x\)-axis at the point \(B\). Find the area of the shaded region enclosed by the curve, the line \(AB\) and the line through \(B\) parallel to the \(y\)-axis. Give your answer in the form \(\frac{\mathrm{e}}{a}\) , where \(a\) is a constant. You must show all your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 448, 920, 466]]<|/det|>
<mark>[10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[332, 492, 665, 512]]<|/det|>
Question 12 is printed on the next page.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 109, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 447, 89]]<|/det|>
Do not use a calculator in this question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 144, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 98, 920, 128]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\frac{6^{p}\times 8^{p + 2}\times 3^{q}}{9^{2q - 3}}\) is equal to \(2^{7}\times 3^{4}\) , find the value of each of the constants \(p\) and \(q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 137]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 395, 144, 413]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 388, 698, 413]]<|/det|>
Using the substitution \(u = x^{\frac{1}{3}}\), or otherwise, solve \(4x^{\frac{1}{3}} + x^{\frac{2}{3}} + 3 = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 396, 920, 414]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
